competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 5 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: Feature Engineering: Extract Group from PassengerId (gggg_pp format), split Cabin into Deck/Num/Side, create TotalExpenditure from RoomService+FoodCourt+ShoppingMall+Spa+VRDeck, use TF-IDF on Name features
Models: Ensemble of XGBoost, LightGBM, CatBoost with Optuna-optimized weights. Use StratifiedKFold cross-validation. Multiple random seeds for robustness.
Advanced techniques: KMeans clustering on features, Group-clustered one-hot encoding, multiplicative features, TF-IDF + PCA on text, optimal cutoff threshold selection

Key EDA insights: Target is balanced (50.4% transported). CryoSleep=True strongly predicts transported. Age 0-18 more likely transported, 18-25 less likely. Spending features (RoomService, FoodCourt, etc.) are highly skewed.
Post-processing: Tune classification threshold to match train set target distribution (~50.4% transported). Use soft voting ensemble of LGBM and CatBoost with 10-fold StratifiedKFold CV.

Optuna hyperparameter tuning: XGBoost best params - lambda=3.06, alpha=4.58, colsample_bytree=0.92, subsample=0.95, learning_rate=0.067, n_estimators=850, max_depth=5. LGBM best - num_leaves=330, learning_rate=0.087, n_estimators=739

Feature engineering from viktortaran: Extract Group and GroupSize from PassengerId, split Cabin into Deck/Num/Side, create TotalSpent, create binary 'Solo' feature, impute missing values using group information
CryoSleep=True has 81.8% transported rate vs 32.9% for CryoSleep=False - strongest predictor. Europa passengers 65.9% transported, Earth 42.4%, Mars 52.3%
Spending features (RoomService, FoodCourt, ShoppingMall, Spa, VRDeck) are highly skewed - median=0 for all, many passengers spend nothing. Log transform or binary indicators recommended.

LazyPredict comparison of 27 classifiers shows gradient boosting models (LGBM, XGBoost, CatBoost) consistently top performers. Simple preprocessing: median imputation, label encoding for categoricals.

Advanced techniques for high accuracy: 1) Target/frequency encoding for high-cardinality categoricals, 2) Log-scaling/binning skewed features, 3) Interaction features (pairwise products, ratios), 4) Bayesian HPO with Optuna, 5) Multi-model ensemble with stacking, 6) AutoGluon for automated ensembling
Group size: Most passengers travel alone (median=1), but groups can be up to 8 people. 6217 unique groups in training data. Group information useful for imputation and feature engineering.
Deck B and C have highest transported rates (73.4% and 68.0%). Deck T has lowest (20%). Starboard side (S) has higher transported rate (55.5%) than Port (45.1%).

VIP passengers have lower transported rate (38.2% vs 50.4% for non-VIP). HomePlanet Europa has highest transported rate (65.8%), Earth lowest (42.3%). Destination 55 Cancri e has highest transported rate (60.3%).

web_research.query: What are the best techniques to achieve very high accuracy in binary classification with tabular data on Kaggle?
web_research.finding:
Achieving very high accuracy on binary‑classification tabular problems on Kaggle is less about a single “magic” model and more about a disciplined pipeline that combines strong baselines, aggressive feature work, careful validation, and powerful ensembling.  The most reliable starting point is a gradient‑boosted‑tree (GBT) framework—LightGBM, CatBoost or XGBoost—because GBTs natively handle missing values, categorical encodings and non‑linear interactions, and they have been shown to dominate Kaggle leaderboards across dozens of competitions ([developer.nvidia.com](https://developer.nvidia.com/blog/the-kaggle-grandmasters-playbook-7-battle-tested-modeling-techniques-for-tabular-data)) ([medium.com](https://medium.com/@marawaneslam145/mastering-gradient-boosting-the-algorithm-that-dominates-kaggle-1d6c96db02af)).  A solid baseline should include:

* **Target / frequency encoding** for high‑cardinality categoricals, plus log‑scaling or binning of skewed numeric features.  
* **Interactio

web_research.query: What are the best feature engineering techniques for passenger transport prediction with spending and demographic features?
web_research.finding:
Passenger transport demand models that incorporate **spending** (e.g., ticket fare, ancillary purchases) and **demographic** information (age, income, occupation) benefit most from a blend of classic preprocessing, engineered interaction/temporal features, and model‑driven feature generation.  

First, raw categorical demographics should be **one‑hot encoded** or, for high‑cardinality fields, transformed into **learned embeddings** so that tree‑based or deep models can treat them as numeric inputs. Continuous spending variables are best **scaled** (standard‑ or min‑max) and any missing values **imputed** (mean/median or model‑based) to avoid bias ([ProjectPro](https://www.projectpro.io/article/8-feature-engineering-techniques-for-machine-learning/423)). Next, create **interaction features** that capture how spending varies across demographic groups (e.g., `spending × age_group`, `spending × income_bracket`) and **temporal aggregates** such as daily/weekly totals, peak‑hour ratios, or l
